title: Source and Relevant Information
text:
I used the Lung Cancer Prediction data-set from Kaggle to complete this model project. This data-set contains information on patients with lung cancer, including their age, gender, air pollution exposure, alcohol use, dust allergy, occupational hazards, genetic risk, chronic lung disease, balanced diet, obesity, smoking, passive smoker, chest pain, coughing of blood, fatigue, weight loss, shortness of breath, wheezing, swallowing difficulty, clubbing of finger nails and snoring.
The data-set contained clean data, as all individuals were actual patients part of a study publish in the journal Natural Medicine about Health Effects of Air Pollution in China. Read more about the article to find out about interesting details of how the study was done, and other conclusions that came out of it.

title: Lung Cancer Prediction by Various Factors
text: Modeling the relationships between lung cancer and other various factors such as air pollution, smoking, obesity, etc. to understand better treatment and prevention of it.

title: Lung Cancer Prediction by Various Factors
text:
Project Summary
Lung Cancer is the 2nd most common cancer affecting the United States in 2024. Using data from from a study done by the journal Nature Medicine on over 462,000 people in China who lived in areas with varying levels of air pollution, we seek to understand the relationship between risk of lung cancer and air pollution. We modeled people living in various atmospheric conditions, a categorical variable, as a categorical function of Lung Cancer Risk. Individuals with worse conditions were more likely to be prone to Lung Cancer.

title: Lung Cancer Prediction by Various Factors
text: Lung Cancer is the 2nd most common cancer affecting the United States in 2024, understanding the causes and predicting the probability of it can allow for the demystification and prevention of the disease. To do so, modelling the data is a great way to visualize the outcomes.

title: Lung Cancer Prediction by Various Factors
section: Air Pollution + Smoking vs. Cancer Risk
text:
Air Pollution + Smoking vs. Cancer Risk
It is a common know fact that smoking has a direct correlation to lung cancer, and one of the greatest determinators of whether or not one can get lung cancer.

Smoking
To find the relationship between lung cancer and smoking to see just by how much it increases risk of getting Lung Cancer, a categorical model can be made:

Formula \[\begin{equation}
\text{level} = \alpha + \beta_1 (\text{smoking}) + \epsilon
\end{equation}\]
Table














Characteristic
Beta
95% CI
1




mu2_(Intercept)
0.56
0.29, 0.85


mu3_(Intercept)
-2.5
-2.9, -2.1


mu2_smoking
-0.17
-0.26, -0.09


mu3_smoking
0.59
0.51, 0.67



1
CI = Credible Interval









Plot of Posterior Prediction (Air Pollution)










As seen in the graph, the risk of lung cancer increases as the level of smoking increases, which is a well know fact, but something interesting happens when the prediction of lung cancer is seen with the level of air pollution.


Air Pollution
To find the relationship between lung cancer and air pollution another categorical model can be made lke thus:

Formula \[\begin{equation}
\text{level} = \alpha + \beta_1 (\text{air\_pollution}) + \epsilon
\end{equation}\]
Table














Characteristic
Beta
95% CI
1

-0.29
-0.60, 0.05

-4.6
-5.3, -4.0


mu2_air_pollution
0.14
0.03, 0.24


mu3_air_pollution
1.1
1.0, 1.3



1
CI = Credible Interval









Plot of Posterior Prediction (Smoking)










Comparing both posterior prediction graphs we can see that they are similiar in terms of trend and probability of risk of lung cancer, leading to an interesting revelation that…

Air pollution level is as bad as smoking for probability of getting lung cancer

title: About Me
text:
profile-picture
My name is Lowell Ethan, I’m a rising junior at Oakdale High. I like to play basketball, make music, and am passionate about computer/data science.

title: About Me
text:
The Project
This project is to visualize, and better understand the Air Pollution in Correlation to Lung Cancer.
This project was created as a part of Kane’s Data Science Bootcamp.
